Description: U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder, U.S. Secretary of Transportation Anthony Foxx, U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York Preet Bharara, Inspector General of the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) Calvin L. Scovel III, National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) Acting Administrator David Friedman and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Deputy Assistant Director Joe Campbell announced a criminal wire fraud charge against Toyota Motor Corporation, an automotive company headquartered in Toyota City, Japan, that designs, manufactures, assembles, and sells Toyota and Lexus brand vehicles. The charge is that TOYOTA defrauded consumers in the fall of 2009 and early 2010 by issuing misleading statements about safety issues in Toyota and Lexus vehicles.The agreement, which is subject to judicial review, requires TOYOTA to pay a $1.2 billion financial penalty - the largest penalty of its kind ever imposed on an automotive company, and imposes on TOYOTA an independent monitor to review and assess policies, practices and procedures relating to TOYOTAs safety-related public statements and reporting obligations.
Agency: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-announces-criminal-charge-against-toyota-motor-corporation-and-deferred

Description: The Department of Justice and the Environment Protection Agency announced a settlement with Toyota Motor Corporation covering Clean Air Act violations involving 2.2 million vehicles manufactured between 1996 and 1998. Toyota agreed to extend the emission-control-system warranty on the vehicles, accelerate its compliance with certain new emission control requirements, pay a $500,000 civil penalty and spend $20 million on a supplemental environmental project. The settlement was expected to cost Toyota an estimated $34 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2003/March/03_enrd_141.htm

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 336112: Light Truck and Utility Vehicle Manufacturing
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and Department of Justice (DOJ) resolved an action with Toyota Motor Credit Corporation, under which Toyota Motor Credit will change its pricing and compensation system to substantially reduce dealer discretion and accompanying financial incentives to mark up interest rates.  Toyota Motor Credit was also required to pay up to $21.9 million in restitution to thousands of African-American and Asian and Pacific Islander borrowers who paid higher interest rates than white borrowers for their auto loans, without regard to their creditworthiness, as a result of its past practices.
Info Source: http://www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/newsroom/cfpb-and-doj-reach-resolution-with-toyota-motor-credit-to-address-loan-pricing-policies-with-discriminatory-effects/

Description: Toyota agreed to pay $29 million to settle a multistate lawsuit  alleging that it concealed safety issues related to sudden, unintended acceleration in vehicles it manufactured and sold.
Info Source: https://www.nj.gov/oag/newsreleases13/pr20130214b.html
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/CivPen/Documents/20130425_toyota.pdf

Description: Toyota Motor Corporation agreed to pay $16 million to settle a lawsuit by the Orange County District Attorney alleging that the automaker concealed safety issues related to unintended acceleration in some vehicles.
Info Source: https://www.ocregister.com/2013/04/05/toyota-settles-with-oc-da-for-16-million/

Description: To resolve allegations that it discriminated against minority customers, Toyota agreed to reform its practices and implement a diversity marketing initiatives that included offers of credit and financial incentives to affected parties, but no value was put on the program. The company also agreed to pay $95,000 to class representatives, $750,000 for consumer education and $10.6 million for plaintiff's legal fees and expenses.
Private Litigation Case Title: Baltimore, et al v. Toyota Motor Credit, et al
Info Source: https://www.nclc.org/litigation/case-index-closed-cases.html#ral

Info Source: https://www.adeq.state.ar.us/downloads/Communications/Enforcement_Actions/2018-03-25_Notice_of_Enforcement_Actions.pdf

Description: Toyota agreed to a $7.9 million settlement stemming from a 1998 recall order for potential defects in evaporative emission system monitors.
Info Source: https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/toyota-settlement

Description: The Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Toyota for alleged failures to comply with its obligations under the Clean Air Act to monitor the vehicles for potential defects in emissions controls and report to the EPA, as well as failing to file reports describing the substance and progress of recalls. Under the terms of the settlement, Toyota will take steps to ensure compliance and pay a civil penalty of $180 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.epa.gov/enforcement/toyota-clean-air-act-emissions-defect-reporting-settlement-information-sheet
